utterances: Mark Solms, do you have a favorite?

Yes, funnily enough, I have a favorite, which has the same importance that Lynn attached to the diagram of that dream in the Project for a Scientific Psychology, but it's a different drawing that I would identify as the, sort of, pivotal, transitional drawing.
It's actually, from an aesthetic point of view, one of the ugliest.
It was drawn in 1886, or thereabouts.
We don't know precisely when it was drawn because it was never published, and, as far as I'm aware, it's being exhibited, now, for the first time.
It's a drawing in which Freud shows that the relationship between the body periphery and the central organ of the brain, especially the cortex of the brain, is a very complicated relationship.
One of Freud's professors, Theodore Meinert(ph), had taught that the body periphery is literally projected onto the cortex, so the cortex contains a sort of map of the body periphery.

And Freud showed in that drawing that the relationship is much more complex than that--that the body periphery--the nerves going from, say, your hands or your feet, arrive at spinal nuclei where they're subtly reordered and then projected onto thalamic nuclei deep in the brain, where they're reordered again, and joined with other inputs, and then projected onto the cortex, where they're reordered again, and joined with, yet, other inputs, and then re-represented in various iterations in the cortex.

And, why that's important, as Freud said in the accompanying text, is that, as we move deeper into the system--as we go from the concrete sensory motor level of the body periphery to the higher levels of the cortex, so we have different principles organizing the representation of the body.
It's not a literal, physical representation of the body, but rather an increasingly abstracted depiction--performing different functions.
It's not the function merely of projecting the surface, but rather of re-representing that surface in relation to other things.
And I think that that drawing, in this sense, introduces what will later become the mind in Freud's theorizing--something which symbolically represents, rather than concretely represents.
Mark Solms, I'm afraid we've run out of time, but I'd like to thank my guests.

Mark Solms is a psychoanalyst and director of the Neuro-Psychoanalysis Center at the New York Psychoanalytic Institute and Lynn Gamwell is the curator of this new exhibit, From Neurology to Psychoanalysis: Sigmund Freud's Drawings and Diagrams of the Mind.
When we come back, a new study of the brain.
Stay with us.
After a long boom cycle, the farm sector is now in its third down year.
Major crop prices are low while expenses remain high.
And that means farmers have to get creative to succeed.
From Iowa Public Radio, Amy Mayer reports.
Modern crop farms in the Corn Belt are sophisticated businesses.
So put aside your notions of bucolic red barn surrounded by a few cows and pull out your best business school vocabulary.
Farming is - we build commodities.
And every individual acre is a unique production facility.
That's David Muth who runs AgSolver, one of many data-driven startups promising to make farms more efficient.
Muth compares each acre of a farm to one store in a chain of coffee shops.
Some locations are profitable, others, not so much.
The question we like to ask is - would we be satisfied if any one of those individual production facilities is operating at a loss?
Probably not, he says.
So what do you do with the coffee shops that are losing money?
Any MBA will tell you you've got to do two things - reduce expenses and stop wasting money.
Let's start with that second one.
Andrew Heineman is driving his old pickup to a field already bright green in early May.
Here they are.
This young farmer has planted about 150 acres of oats, a crop not seen on his family's corn/soybean farm in his lifetime.
Found out this is kind of one of our lower profit farms.
So we were trying to figure out a way to kind of offset kind of the stuff from $3 corn.
Oats are risky.
But Heineman did the math and ran his idea past Iowa State University Extension agronomist Mark Johnson, who told him...
This would be a great year to try to raise them if you've got a market.
Now back to the other business school lesson - cut costs.
Modern seeds are packed with special traits that protect them from insects or fungus.
Farmers could cut seed costs in half if they dropped all the traits.
Most guys are going to only (unintelligible) back some traits.
And so maybe they're only going to save 25 percent or 20 percent.
But still, today's corn - that's still a pretty good chunk of money.
We're talking thousands, maybe tens of thousands of dollars.
Ryan Bristle farms about 20 miles southeast of Heineman.
You take a little bit of a gamble when you try to redo some things.
But we did reduce some of our traits.
He's also using a website app that Iowa State has developed.
He simply plugs in his location, the expected corn price and the cost of fertilizer to find out just how much to use.
Bristle will apply less this year because a small bump from extra fertilizer won't generate enough additional corn to pay for itself.
But he's cautious.
You don't want to do it where it's detrimental to your yield 'cause at the end of the day, yield is still king.
And that's what's going to drive your return.
(SOUNDBITE OF ENGINE STARTING)
That's correct.
But people are real, and you know, and you have to deal with both parts.
And if people are anxious, that's a health effect also.
The NAACP announced its cutting about a third of its staff and temporarily closing its regional offices.
Hayes insisted the move won't affect the group's local offices.
Three straight years of financial trouble have forced the NAACP to dip into its saving, using more than $10 million from a rainy-day fund.
Though the group's all but certain to rebound, questions remain, how did this happen?
Will a smaller, more concentrated NAACP better serve the community?
And how did their money troubles compare to other non-profits today?
For more, we turn to NEWS & NOTES - resident number cruncher, Julianne Malveaux, author, economist, and president of Bennett College.
Julianne, welcome.
Thanks, Farai.
How are you?
Now I'm going to have to start calling you lady president now, president of Bennett College.
You're new…
Just as a friend, that works.
Just friend.
All right.
Congratulations again.
And let's move on to the NAACP.
It's not bankrupt.

In fact, there was a worst crisis less than 20 years ago but they have dipped into their savings for $10 million, that sort of sounds like someone with a 401-K well before retirement - kind of liquidating it.
How much is that money - that $10 million - relative to what the organization exist on generally?
The issue loosely(ph) endowment and the issue is the money they've set aside, and it's never good to dip into your reserves, especially three years in a row.
So when you look at this, it's very very challenging.
Farai, the real question is, they had never had a capital campaign before Bruce Gordon came in.
When he came in, he stated a goal of raising $100 million in corporate contributions by 2009.
Obviously, with Brother Gordon gone, that's not going to happen, and of course, fingers are pointing all over the place.

But you haven't seen the major contributions come into the NAACP that you would expect to see if they had made our civil rights a value proposition, not only for corporate America, but even for everyday Americans.
So, when you say a value position, it basically boils down to what have you done for me, and not necessarily in a selfish way.
A lot of people say well, I may not be in a position where I need to fight for civil rights on a day-to-day basis, but I know it makes this a better country.
And so, that may be a value proposition.
What do you think the NAACP is lacking right now in offering value, if anything?
Well, I think they're lacking - the NAACP seems to be lacking a compelling statement about what they are about.
And I think that this most recent move to cut the regional offices further erodes the sense of mission.
The regional offices as well the local branches, over 2,000 of them, are the individuals' connection to the NAACP.

In another life, Farai, I was vice president of the San Francisco branch of the NAA, and they had a laboring industry night(ph) where people who have been discriminated against, or had job challenges could come and talk and find out if there was an attorney who might represent them.
If it was something more simple that could be resolved with a phone call, or it would just something that was office funk and not a big civil rights case, but people felt connected because of that.
When you cut the connection, you cut the incentive for people really to contribute.
And value proposition doesn't mean it's worth it in terms of money or what have you done for me lately.
It's just, what would my dollars bring?
Now, the other thing, you know, there are only half-a-million members of the NAACP.
There are probably 35 million African-American people, so you do the math, just three percent of us think it's important to spend $30 a year, that's what the membership cost, $30 a year on the NAACP.
So, first of all, I think their membership cost are very low, but secondly, when have they last done membership outreach, you know, try to get people in.
It's not…
Let's talk about age for a second, because it's - I know that the average age of the average member is up in AARP territory, and that's - you got to love the baby boomer.
The AARP territory loan.

No, I'm saying, you have to love the baby boomer generation but African-Americans, on average, are in their - the average or median age is in the 30s, so there's a whole lot of people who are adults, taxpaying adults, who aren't being marketed too effectively by the NAACP, isn't that correct?
I think that's absolutely correct.
And I think when you look at that 64-member board, which is a whole other issue.
I mean, let me say that again, the 64-member board, one might ask a question, how many people on that board are under 35 or under 40, and there aren't very many.
You have civil rights icons, like Julian Bond(ph) and many others, who definitely belong on that board and have paid their dues.
But you have to have a mix, and I think this is an issue that we're tackling throughout black America, a mixed generation and you have to have younger people, many of whom could be key contributors.
I mean, where has the NAACP been in all those swirling conversation about African-American women's images, and the Imus and all of that.
I would posit that we could gain from having younger voices and younger voices who also have influence and dollars.

When we really think about the centennial coming down the pipe so shortly and the institution being so troubled, could there be - instead of a 100th anniversary celebration of the NAACP as virtual funeral?
Could that be the worst-case scenario?
Farai, I really don't think so.

I think that - I think this is a wake-up call when you see a staff cut, a 40 percent staff cut, when you see some other things, the organization is being pushed and forced to move into the 21st century.
But he apparently had no choice in terms of differences in styles.
We can't do 21st-century civil rights using 19th-century civil rights methodology.
